Mr. Speaker, today I want to take this opportunity to pay tribute to Father Rolland Brunelle.
Recently Father Brunelle was made a knight of the National Order of Quebec. He was awarded this high honour by the premier of Quebec, in recognition of his exceptional contribution to the community.
This award was well deserved. Father Brunelle has dedicated his life to teaching music and for more than 50 years has passed on his love of music to hundreds of young people, some of whom have become famous musicians.
Throughout his career Father Brunelle won the admiration and respect of the community in Joliette, which expressed its appreciation by celebrating his 50th anniversary as a teacher of music last year.
Father Brunelle's contribution and his dedication to young people and the local community are examples to us all.
On behalf of the House I wish to congratulate Father Brunelle on receiving this well deserved award.

Mr. Speaker, it is beyond understanding that Canada still recognizes and supports the current military dictatorship in Myanmar which continues to rule by force and which has been twice rejected by Myanmar's 40 million citizens through widespread demonstrations and the ballot box.
In attempts to further delay transferring its power to the National League for Democracy, which won the 1990 general elections, the illegitimate dictatorship is waging a cruel war against Muslims and ethnic minorities, causing almost 200,000 refugees to flee to neighbouring countries. Indeed, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees in Geneva issued an urgent plea for assistance, saying the situation has turned into one of the world's major refugee crises. Amnesty International has confirmed reports of widespread human rights violations, including torture, rape and killings.
I call on this government to recognize the Myanmar national coalition government as the government legally elected by the people, support UN economic sanctions and an arms embargo on Myanmar, suspend all Petro-Canada operations and to redirect all government to government and multilateral assistance to the refugees and those in legitimate need.
March 26, 1992

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Multiculturalism and Citizenship; Parliamentary Secretary to the Secretary of State of Canada
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I support what was said yesterday in the House by the hon. member for Laurier-Sainte-Marie about the resumptions of negotiations between the union and Nationair in the presence of Mr. Courchesne, the mediator appointed by the Minister of Labour.
Time is of the essence, even if Mr. Nolan, the Toronto based leader of the flight attendants union who is also employed by Air Canada, has said repeatedly that closing down Nationair did not bother him at all.
It is hard to understand why a union affiliated with the QFL, whose president, Mr. Daoust, says he is very concerned about the well-being of Nationair employees, could make such inappropriate and indeed dangerous statements.
The campaign to boycott, smear and destroy Mirabel's biggest carrier most stop.
In any case, in view of QFL leader Daoust's dedication to the interests of Quebec workers, I am confident that with a show of good will on both sides, negotiations will be resumed.
It is time a settlement was reached. The hon. member for Laurier-Sainte-Marie and myself are prepared to provide some form of special mediation, if necessary, to speed up the settlement of this dispute before it is too late.

Mr. Speaker, I join with others in the House today to express my sadness and that of my party and leader at the death of Barbara Frum. Ms. Frum had a long, varied and accomplished career in journalism. Throughout and until the end she brought curiosity and insight to virtually every interview and every issue she approached.
She became one of the pre-eminent journalists in our nation's history. She succeeded because she knew the issues. She made them understandable for the rest of us. She asked the questions people wanted answered and cared about how the issues touched our lives.
She accomplished all of this as a woman in what had been a very male profession. She was, is and will be for a long time, a role model and inspiration to generations of young women. If the face and character of journalism have changed in Canada, Barbara Frum was certainly at the centre of that change.
My leader said today that perhaps more than anything else, Barbara Frum was a guest we welcomed into our home every night. Her presence will be missed. The sadness we express today is a sadness I know that is shared by all Canadians.
On behalf of myself, my leader and my party, I offer our heartfelt condolences to Ms. Frum's family and her friends.

Mr. Speaker, echoing the comments of my colleague for Kamloops, like many millions of Canadians, I am shattered by the death of Barbara Frum.
As a journalist by profession, I met Barbara and associated with her on a number of occasions. I was even honoured to be interviewed by Canada's finest woman journalist on radio's As It Happens and CBC-TVs The Journal over the years from heaven knows where.
I did not necessarily share Barbara Frum's political views, but I am one Canadian who greatly admired her objective approach to journalism and her unabashed way of questioning anybody who needed to be questioned.
Barbara's sense of values and her forthright statements of those values, which you could sense just by watching her eyes, made her one of the giants of the Canadian broadcasting industry.
Barbara Frum will be missed by her legion of Canadian fans. I know I will miss her.

March 26, 1992

Mr. Speaker, we were all saddened this morning when we woke to the news of the death of Barbara Frum at the early age of 54. She had struggled valiantly these last few years with leukaemia, heroically never letting her pain show to millions of Canadians every night.
One of Canada's greatest journalists, she was a role model and pioneer for women and set extraordinary standards of professionalism.
We first became aware of Barbara Frum's insightful interviewing skills on CBC Radio through As It Happens, as we were kept updated on Canadian public affairs.
In 1982 she left radio, breaking into CBC television with The Journal. For a decade Barbara Frum entered our homes nightly, bringing us in-depth interviews with world leaders from a Canadian perspective, as well as keeping us informed about issues affecting Canada in an ever probing way. She shall be sorely missed by family, friends and the Canadian public. Heartfelt condolences.
May her memory be blessed and may the mourners be comforted among all those who mourn in Zion and Jerusalem.
Y'hee zichron baruch. Hamakom yinachem etchem betoch shaare tizion vYerushalayim.

Mr. Ken James (Sarnia-Lambton) Mr. Speaker, the April 1992 issue of Chatelaine has recently hit the news stands. Included in this issue is an article listing the top 10 towns and small cities in Canada in which to live. The article boasts that those chosen towns and cities have an irrepressible spirit, while being safe, affordable and neighbourly.
It is with great pleasure and pride that I inform all members that Sarnia, Ontario, has been included in this top 10 list. With a good regional employment rate, relatively low housing costs, an established economic base and a strong sense of community, Sarnia has always topped the list for myself, of course, and all residents of our area.
I am pleased that the magazine has acknowledged what the people of Sarnia have known for a long time.
Now all Canadians will know what a great place Sarnia is to live, work and raise a family.

Mr. Speaker, the future of Canada's only national English as a Second Language organization is in jeopardy.
TESL Canada, a non-profit organization, depends largely upon grants from the federal government for funding. Seven months ago, there was a proposal submitted to the Secretary of State to continue a program entitled "Community Support and Participation Program" for the development of an ESL learners' national network.
This is the fourth year of the program. The decision to fund or not to fund is at the minister's discretion. When an official was asked whether the program would be funded, the official answered: "I do not know".
Will this government commit today to funding the ESL program? Will this government commit to the future of new Canadians? Will this government recognize the contributions of immigrants to our society?
Finally, will the minister ensure the survival of this important program?

Mr. Speaker, speaking to members of the Canadian Club in Montreal, including 10 representatives from Hydro Quebec, Chief Billy Diamond of the Waskaghanish Cree stated that aboriginal people wanted to be partners in resource development on their lands so as to enjoy the financial benefits and limit any negative impact on the natural and human environment. He went on to say that it was necessary to set up a partnership with non-native entrepreneurs and establish a better relationship with the government so that native concerns would be given due consideration and long-term development would benefit consumers in the north as well as the south.
March 26, 1992

According to Mr. Diamond, private and public developers will start taking aboriginal people seriously when they have no other alternative.

Mr. Speaker, today in Halifax the Minister of Veterans Affairs has finally announced that the government will introduce legislation to recognize the service in wartime of Canada's merchant mariners.
On my own behalf and on behalf of our party, and particularly the member for Regina-Lumsden who has worked on this cause for years, we applaud the announcement as far as it goes.
Regretfully, however, the announcement falls short of acceptance by the government of the unanimous report of the Standing Committee on National Defence and Veterans Affairs which called for the full recognition of merchant mariners as veterans with the same status and benefits as Armed Forces veterans.
In World War II and other conflicts, Canada's merchant mariners served this country with courage and sacrifice. Finally they are getting some of the recognition they deserve. I am sure all members of this House will honour their contribution to freedom and pledge to work to see that the promised legislation fully meets the recognition to which they are fully entitled.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, this is indeed a great day for Canada's merchant seamen. Just a few hours ago the Minister of Veterans Affairs announced in Halifax that Canada's wartime merchant mariners will soon be enjoying all the benefits now available to veterans of our wartime Armed Forces.
Merchant mariners do have some access to most of the programs and benefits available to other veterans, but
there are significant omissions and differences that really rankle them.
New legislation will be introduced to close all the gaps. This means that long-term care will be available to the merchant navy veterans. More of them will have the opportunity to qualify for the veterans independence program. The old six-month restriction has been torpedoed, as have obstacles to disability pensions.
Ever since the end of the Second World War, merchant mariners have been fighting for veteran status. I am proud that my government is the one to do something about it and I commend this minister for making it happen.
On March 17 I told the House about my late uncle, Captain Ernest Shatford of the merchant navy. These changes have come too late for him, but I know he would be absolutely delighted that his shipmates have won their battle.

Mr. Speaker, the Core Area Initiative Program of Winnipeg has five days left to live. It is losing funding from both the Tory federal government and the Tory provincial government. Meanwhile, Winnipeg and particularly inner city residents stand to suffer.
How can this government allow a Liberal initiative that has taught job skills to over 2,600 citizens, most of whom remain employed, to die?
As well, the core area initiative works to get young Canadians off the streets and helps revitalize the face of the inner city. Is the problem with this government lack of commitment, failure of leadership, or both? I tell this government it has only five days left to prove its worth to Winnipegers.
Give the core area initiative a new lease on life. Do not let this success story perish. It has served Winnipegers well.

March 26, 1992
Oral Questions

Mr. Speaker, I would like to join my colleagues in celebrating Barbara Frum's life.
She was more than the reigning queen of Canadian broadcasting. She was a case study in courage.
The first time I met Barbara Frum was in a Toronto television studio 10 years ago. We arrived at the makeup room at the same time and I was struck by her appearance. After watching her on television for so long, I was surprised to see that in person her hair was thin and her features troubled.
Only later did I learn of her battle with leukaemia, a battle which would have ended weaker lives a lot sooner. Barbara's battle, not to excel in life but simply to keep on living, was an inspiration.
I came later to meet her entrepreneurial husband, Murray, and her son, David, who has become in his own right, an outstanding journalist. The Frum family, by any standard, is exceptional and special.
This day we are sad at Barbara Frum's passing. But we are also inspired by her.
Those of us who knew her, who were challenged by her on national television, who felt her energy and her bite, know that this is not just the loss of an important journalist, it is the loss of a person who had an appetite for life. It is the loss of someone who challenged disease and death the same way she took on the politicians and that, as many of us in this House know, was with a fury.

Mr. Speaker, I join my colleagues in expressing our appreciation on the recent announcement by the Minister of Veterans Affairs in considering merchant seamen for veterans' benefits.
I was a member of the Standing Committee on Defence and Veterans Affairs which studied this matter. The testimony that we heard from the merchant seamen involved and those who participated on behalf of their colleagues, the merchant sailors who were involved in the world wars and particularly World War II, was commendable.
I recall, as a young boy in Newfoundland, the experiences of those involved even in the coastal trade, plus the Atlantic Canadians who were involved in very dangerous trips across the Atlantic and indeed up as far as Murmansk.
I am speaking on behalf of my party and the leader of the Liberal Party, who is delighted to see that this action has been taken by the government and that the brave action of those merchant seamen who helped us in the wars at sea and their contribution are finally being fully appreciated by the government.

Mr. Speaker, Canadians want this government to invest in their future. This government does not have to take my word for it, it only has to read the results of a recent survey from the hon. member for Mississauga South.
More than 70 per cent of respondents were in favour of allowing unemployed Canadians to continue to collect benefits while attending school and more than 80 per cent of the respondents were also in favour of the government spending more money to finance training programs.
It is imperative, however, that the training funds should not be taken from the unemployment insurance account. The government pulled out of its financial commitment to the account through the adoption of Bill C-21 at the beginning of this recession.
It is time for this government to get back in and show its commitment to the future of Canadian workers.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Acting Prime Minister and concerns the release this morning of the report on the inquiry into the Diyden crash.
March 26, 1992

Oral Questions
I would like to say at the outset of this series of questions that I am sure all Canadians were relieved to hear Justice Moshansky say this morning that some of his concerns about aviation safety have been and are being acted upon. However, he also was clear in stating that the Air Ontario crash at Dryden did not just happen, it was allowed to happen, effectively laying at the foot of this government the death of 24 people.
This conclusion is a very serious one to which the government must respond. Will the government, in the face of this conclusion by Mr. Justice Moshansky and the grave consequences of such a fundamental mistake in the government's policy, accept its responsibility? How does the government propose to make retribution for its policy mistake?

First of all, Mr. Speaker, I think the hon. member for Ottawa South, who was at the press conference this morning, knows that I have indicated that safety in the air in Canada has improved tremendously over the past decade. In 1981 there were 700 aircraft accidents in Canada. In 1991 there were 449 accidents.
We will never be satisfied until we have a zero accident rate, but I think the fact that the situation has improved by 35 per cent over a period of 10 years is an indication that our priority has been on safety.
The report we received this morning is very exhaustive and comprehensive. It contains 191 recommendations. I have indicated that since August of last year I have established an implementation team consisting of 20 persons from Transport Canada and all other segments of the aviation industry to implement these 191 recommendations.
Right now we have already completed 33 of these recommendations. We have indicated that we concur with 61 of the recommendations and action is underway, so already 49 per cent of the 191 recommendations have been implemented. Of the others, the implementation team will start work on them immediately. [DOT]
I have taken the commitment that I will make public an interim report on the work of that team within the next six months.

Mr. Speaker, according to the inquiry made public this morning, it is clear that the air safety of the Canadian public is not a priority for this government.
I quote the Moshansky report:
The need for increased resources within the Aviation Regulation Directorate to meet the growth and demands expected to be generated by the policy of economic regulatory reform was predicted and well documented in several reports and studies.
Since this government has not acted on the many warnings given to it, would the minister agree to set up an independent task force on air safety, which would report regularly to Parliament on the government's performance in regulating air safety?

Mr. Speaker, I would like to point out that in 1984-85 there were 456 inspectors at Transport Canada. In 1991-92 there are 569 inspectors. This indicates, I think, that safety continues to be our prime concern.
I would point out that there were five million movements of aircraft in Canada last year. We had 449 accidents. While we are not complacent, I think this indicates that our record for safety is not diminishing, it is improving and this has been confirmed by the report of the Transportation Safety Board over the past few years.

Mr. Speaker, the minister really misses the point here. What happened and what Justice Moshansky has reported is that what occurred in the mid-1980s in Canada was a mid-air collision between contradictory federal government policies, that of airline deregulation and deficit reduction.
I quote from the report:
The effect of economic regulatory reform combined with deficit reduction-created a synergy that, in my opinion based on the evidence before this Commission, had an adverse impact on the effective application of safety standards."
Why did the government fail to ensure public safety in the air?

Mr. Speaker, I repeat that we received from Justice Moshansky this morning a very comprehensive and thorough report

March 26, 1992
Oral Questions
containing 191 recommendations. Forty-nine per cent of these recommendations are already under way.
When Justice Moshansky tabled two interim reports earlier, action was taken on these recommendations immediately, and the safety record has been excellent because we have reduced the number of accidents in Canadian skies over the past 10 years.
The indication that Justice Moshansky himself has given is that he has confidence in the safety standards of aviation in Canada. Upon being questioned by a member of the press this morning, he reiterated that he himself has no qualms about travelling with air carriers in Canadian skies.

Mr. Speaker, in the words of Justice Moshansky, this accident did not happen by chance, it was allowed to happen. It could have been avoided.
As far back as 1985, the Nielsen task force report advised this government to "immediately increase the resources devoted to licensing, certification and enforcement in the regulation of air safety". Increase them.
Why did the government choose to ignore that advice, actually decrease resources and thereby jeopardize safety in the name of economic policy?

Mr. Speaker, first of all I would like to mention that I informed the public this morning that I have no problems with the 191 recommendations contained in the report of Mr. Justice Moshansky.
I have also indicated that if this report was a decision of the court, I would have immediately asked our lawyers to file an appeal. I strenuously reject and object to the language that has been used that tends to put the blame on the thousands of men and women who have been, and still are active in Transport Canada and in the employment of air carriers.
To connote that these people may have allowed an accident to happen is sheer nonsense.

Mr. Speaker, the hundreds of men and women in Transport Canada, the foot soldiers of Transport Canada are not to blame. They were the ones who came to this minister and blamed the minister and his policies for this action. That is what happened.

Mr. Speaker, I believe I had something like 13 minutes left for my remarks.
I want to begin with a little bit of history which I think is important. Medicare began in this country in one of the poorest of our provinces in the middle of very depressed economic conditions by a government that did not represent a large population.
It is important to take it back to those roots. It clarifies something which is vital to understanding what medicare is all about. Medicare is not free medical care for anybody. Medicare is about the co-operative movement. It is about people bonding together to provide for themselves as a group those things which they really could not accomplish as individuals.
I watched Canada AM this morning. I saw a very prominent Canadian physician talk about free medical care. That is wrong. There is no free medical care in Canada that I know of. You and I, Mr. Speaker, all of us in Canada pay for our own medical care through our taxation process. It is a co-operative movement. It is not about getting something for nothing. It is about sharing all of our resources collectively to provide for a common need: medical care.
Until about 1977 there was an agreement in force between our provinces and the federal government that the cost of his particular program would be shared evenly between the provinces and the federal government on a roughly a 50 / 50 basis.
I happen to have been the health critic for the New Democratic Party in the Ontario legislature at the time when block funding was introduced. At that time many of us had a concern that centred around that shared cost.
There were many advantages, I suppose, to block funding, to changing the funding formulas. They became more complicated. Supposedly they provided more flexibility, but the one thing that concerned many of us was

March 26, 1992
Supply
that it would take away that basic share, that simple straightforward notion that the provinces and the federal government would be equal participants in medicare.
That, of course, has turned out to be the truth. The shift has been downward. One can argue and of course many will that more dollars go to some provinces than others, that more dollars go now and the percentages may be less, but the truth is that most of our provinces are well below the shared equal funding technique that was used in 1977. Most of them have dropped to somewhere in the low to mid-thirties as a percentage of the funding for medicare that they get in their province.
In a place like Ontario, or Quebec, or any of our industrialized provinces that are very hard hit by this depression, there is an immense cash flow problem at the moment. It has put traumatic squeezes on a number of things, and one of them is medicare.
As a critic who had an opportunity in the 1970s to go around and look at hospital and health care in Ontario- and many people here have had the same opportunity- as you go across Canada you will see some magnificent concepts in providing medical care. You will see some of the world's finest technology. You will see some of the world's finest practitioners. You will see some of the greatest facilities we have ever been able to conceive in terms of providing medical care in place. You will also see some of the problems that people talk about, hospitals across the road from one another that do not even talk to one another, let alone co-ordinate the care that they provide as new technology comes into the field of health care.
Vast expenditures of money are needed now that were not even conceived of 20 or 30 years ago. We have equipment that costs $1 million or $2 million just in capital costs to get the equipment in place. Then of course one facility wants to have exactly the same kinds of equipment as the facility across the road, and across Canada.
Many people have tried their best to co-ordinate the provision of health care services, to provide district health councils, to look at community health care clinics, to look at health care centres, to provide for prevention, to look at a number of ways in which one could be more cost effective in the providing of medical care for our citizens.
It is not an easy task and there are those who work in the health care field across Canada who have been aware of this for many years now and have been trying to improve the use of tax dollars. They know it is difficult. There are a number of vested interests at work that have key decision-making positions.
I am often reminded that in many of our urban centres with high-tech facilities, downtown Toronto being an example, some days you will find the world's finest physicians practising medicine, with great technology and great care, and great back-up teams.
Other days you will find virtually no physicians at work in that hospital facility and the care is provided by nurses, technicians and other people who have been given special kinds of training on special kinds of equipment.
The nature of the provision of medical care has changed a lot in the last two decades, and it is about to change a good deal more. Provincial governments all across Canada are struggling now to turn the provision of health care into something that is non-traditional.
In many parts of the country others who were the first people into the medical care system struggle, for example, midwives across Canada-even though it seems that the giving of birth is something that has been around for a long time, and midwifery as a profession has been around for a long time-have not been recognized for very long. In the giving of birth there is a range of facilities available, from midwives in the home to very high-tech units in urban centres.
We try to match up how we get people from rural areas or the far north for example into these high-tech centres and provide transportation systems that are useful. That is not an easy thing to do but I am aware that people are trying to do that. The unfortunate thing is to introduce a cost squeeze in the middle of this or to divert the argument into something like user fees as being a solution is unfortunate.
Now these are not new notions. They have been around for some time. For example, in many parts of Canada we have looked south of the border and we have said: "We are not going to establish some new technology in the provision of care for the human heart, when somewhere across the border there is a similar institution that has all of the equipment and personnel now.
March 26, 1992

Why don't we send our people down there?" We have tried that.
One of the lessons we have learned is that in the United States health care is a business, as opposed to Canada where it is something other than a business. But in the United States, the first motive driving the health care system is making money. The Americans accept that; Canadians do not.
In Canada, if a doctor challenges the right or the ability of a patient to pay for health care at the door of the hospital, there is quite a fuss about that. Every once in a while an incident of this kind happens. There is quite a fuss because Canada is a place where supposedly, you cannot be denied care simply because someone has challenged your ability to pay. That is news in Canada. That is not news in the United States. In the United States that is daily practice at almost every hospital, because almost every hospital is not a public facility but rather a private business. So there are distinctions to be made.
For a long while in Canada we used to say: "Well, in some fields we simply do not have the facilities". An example of this would be in matters of addiction, drug addiction in particular. "Why don't we use some of those wonderful facilities we hear about in the United States and send our people down there?"
We soon find out about the business part of health care in the United States. We soon find out that there is absolutely no accountability in the process at all. If an American hospital is offered an unending amount of money, it will take the unending amount of money. No question about it. And the provision of care is the second consideration, not the first.
We have learned some hard lessons. In many of our provincial governments and in many of our local hospitals we are now going through the long tough grind of trying to provide reasonable, rational health care for our citizens. That is not an easy task.
If there was a simple solution to this it would have been thought of long ago. There is one thing that is just beginning to dawn. This whole concept is just beginning to come back to people like myself, the politicians in Canada. That is that there is very little we can do in Canada that does not sooner or later wind up at the door of a hospital, at a medicare facility. Now we do not think of that very often, but it is true.

I was reminded a little while ago when we embarked upon great campaigns informing people about AIDS and about the use of drugs of exactly how many people die in this country because of those compared to the number of people who die in this country because of accidents on our highways. It is dramatic.
Now all of us would tend to say: "Oh yes, the use of drugs. That is directly respondent to a medical care system". But the connection between the number of people who die on our highways and in hospitals is made most dramatically by those people who are involved in the accidents, and not thought of often by those who are not.
Workers who die in the workplace because of the conditions there are not always thought of as being a medicare matter. It is sometimes considered to be workers' rights or occupational health and safety. Occasionally environmental considerations come into it. But when workers get sick because of the place where they earn their living, the second place they go to is the hospital, the medical care system.
We had a committee on child poverty. They began to talk a little bit about how sensible it is to take a young mother with poor nutrition habits, who has a child within her, and refuse to feed her before the child is born. At a certain point in time, people say that a child is an expense and when the child is bom we will know how to cope with that expense. But until the child is bom we do not recognize that and we are not prepared to deal with that. Even a hard-headed business person ought to be able to recognize the cost effectiveness of seeing that the mother and child are fed properly as opposed to not doing that and then dealing with the medical ramifications for the rest of the child's life. Those of us who have been teachers have seen that in our schools. Those of us who have been social workers have seen that on our streets.
The ramifications of almost all that we do in our society come back to our medical care system. That is a tragedy that has not been dealt with. One should look at the hard-headed economics of this. I suspect the government of the day wants only to look at the economics of it but look at the long-term economics of it. Look at the cost to Canada, the cost to our taxpayers. Look at the cost to our citizens of not providing decent health care, a

Mr. Speaker, I welcome the comments made by the previous speaker especially because of his experience in the provincial legislature before coming to this House.

The complaint that I hear most often from the hospitals is that the costs of running a hospital have gone up drastically. This is through no fault of the hospitals.
As an example, they tell me of the increase in UI payments that the hospitals have to make, in workmen's compensation payments, the OHIP costs and the pay equity costs. These are all additional costs that have been brought in by the federal government with the UI increase and by the provincial governments with the pay equity. That total varies from hospital to hospital, but the increases have gone up as much as 15 per cent and more.
Now they tell me that what the government, the provincial NDP government, is giving the hospitals is a one per cent increase. Now how can a hospital operate when two higher levels of government have laid on a 15 per cent increase in operating a hospital and the NDP government comes along and gives a one per cent increase.
With the hon. member's experience here and in the provincial legislature, I would like to hear some concrete suggestion how we can come out of this. The hospitals cannot survive at this pace. It is the motion of the NDP. I wonder if we could have a concrete suggestion here to solve this dilemma.

Mr. Speaker, I welcome the question particularly since I visited most of those institutions, when the Tories were the government in Ontario and later on when the Liberals were the government in Ontario. The arguments have not really changed a great deal.
It comes down to this. Through three political parties, we have all come to the same conclusion. There is a need to sort out, not in the short-term but in the long run, how our institutions function. For example, I saw the premier of Ontario address the problem in a way that I think is substantive and worth while and I would recommend to governments across Canada.
The Liberals, when they were the government in Ontario, closed hospitals down. It did not do much good. That has been tried. That is not a solution. When the Tories and the Liberals were in government in Ontario, they closed hospital beds. That is not a solution. The alternatives, user fees, closing beds, closing hospitals, are not solutions because they are not the problem.
The solution that has been put forward by many across Canada now is the one that all of us should use as our model and should start to think about. That is, all who are part and parcel of the health care system, not governments on high, not administrators on high, not doctors on high, not anyone on high, but everyone who is involved in the process must now sit down and rationalize the whole system of providing medical care.
It should go from top to bottom, not excluding anyone, starting with the chief administrative officer in any hospital and going right down to the person who cleans the floors. Each and every one of them should be an active participant in evaluating and assessing and deciding how the system will go from there. That is part of the solution.

Mr. Speaker, when the Liberals were the government in Ontario I supported the introduction of what was referred to as a smart card. In fact, the premier of Ontario lets his actions do his talking and not his accusations. He will be judged by what he has done. Even a few government members have taken the trouble to point out that it has been Liberal federal governments that have established the building blocks of medicare and hospital programs throughout this country. Even they acknowledge that we are on the side of what is right because history speaks with its facts on behalf of what we have done. We will be judged by our record.
Here is the NDP record. I am only going to read part of it here, largely because I cannot see all of this writing without my glasses. In the central region in this last budget, can you believe because we are talking about universality and accessibility, you have got to have a facility to go to. You have got to have health professionals for any assistance that you need. But where are they? You can maintain the principle of universality and accessibility to everybody, but if you close the door on them, and you do not provide the service, what good is that rhetoric?
In the central region, York County hospital will lay off 90 employees and close 90 acute care beds. In the Hamilton-Niagara region, Joseph Brant Memorial Hospital plans to lay off 80 full-time and part-time employees. In addition to staff reductions, the hospital will close a 34-bed acute care unit, cut another by 12 beds and cut financing for its community health service centre.
If this is what the NDP government of Ontario wants to put forward as its indication, its hallmark, its standard of what constitutes universal health care and medicare, what it considers is standard for the principle of universal access to medicare throughout the country, then I would hope that the mover of this motion would have the courage to stand up and say, "Yes, we will be judged by our actions while we wag our tongue at those nasty Liberal premiers who are actually considering what might happen".
And for what? Because the member for Oshawa says we must take a look at all the ways to save money. We have to look at this because we do not have any extra cash.
Is this in fact true? I indicated earlier in a question that the province of Ontario, when the NDP government took control, was in a surplus situation, no deficit.

It seems we have discovered that when truth speaks even stones hear.

It's all those Amex cards they carry around.

Of course it must be some of those credit cards. You are right.
If the principle of universality was not the main theme, if the medical health program was not the main theme, if the hospital system in Ontario was not the main theme, or the encouragement of all health care professionals to stay in the province of Ontario, then for what did they raise this money?

The provinces find themselves in a position where they are just unable to foot the bill. The very area where this federal government has cut back is in the transfers for those very things.
As the hon. member for Broadview-Greenwood has pointed out on many occasions, they have allowed through our tax system, a decrease in the amount of money that flows to the Government of Canada through our income tax system from very wealthy Canadians and very wealthy corporations in this country. It thereby decreases again the revenues flowing to the provincial governments through our income tax system.
When filling out an income tax form, if you are residing in the province of Newfoundland, you fill out

the form and come to the federal tax payable. Then you take 62 per cent of it and that is what goes to the provincial government.
When there are individuals in this nation who make $500,000 a year and pay not one penny of income tax as we have under this government, and the numbers are rising, then you know that the revenues to the provinces are drying up.
The Auditor General put it quite simply back in 1987 when he said in his report that members of this Chamber and the Parliament of Canada are always trying to produce a more energy efficient engine and no matter how much they make it energy efficient, they are still finding that the same amount of fuel is being consumed, until they discover tiny holes in the gas tank. The Government of Canada has done nothing about it. Provinces like Newfoundland have found that through the tax system their revenues have dried up. Their revenues have started to go down. Mr. Speaker, as I mentioned earlier to my colleague, I would not be sitting here today if it were not for the debating skills of the right hon. member for Vancouver Quadra. If the NDP had not taken so many cheap shots at him who knows where we could have been, maybe on the other side of the House.

I have a paper here in my hands from Michael M. Rachlis, MD, who wrote the book Second Opinion. He is a constituent of mine. He is a member of the New Democratic Party and is probably one of the most brilliant people in this country when it comes to reform and change in the health care system in this country. I am sure that members of the New Democratic Party agree with my judgment on Dr. Rachlis.
I have put this paper forward. I have put his book forward on the floor of this House more than once, and I will continue to do so. The NDP should go to Dr. Rachlis' book which talks about ways and means of reforming and bringing more efficiency to the health care system of Canada. Had that been the thrust of our debate today we would have served the people of Canada a lot better.

Mr. Speaker, I am delighted to hear the member talk about Michael Rachlis' position. If members have heard his position, one of the things that he diametrically opposes is any form of user fees, a two-tiered health care system or deterrent fees.
What I find very interesting in this whole discussion today is that the Liberals are standing up and saying we should not have raised the issue. Shame on us, we should not have raised the issue. I have not heard any of them stand up and flatly say: "We in the Liberal Party at all levels, federally and provincially, repudiate the introduction of user fees."
That is what is sticking in their craw, they cannot say that because there are several prominent Liberals in this country who are repeatedly advocating that as a solution to medicare.
We have not denied that there are problems, that there have to be changes and innovations. We certainly have not denied that the financial squeeze that the Liberals and now the Tories have put on the health care system is creating problems. But we have said clearly: "One solution is we will not abandon our principles".
I would ask the member if he will stand up and on behalf of his party, at all levels of government, repudiate the introduction of user fees and deterrent fees.

The people of Canada-
Will you or won't you?
Yes. I will tell you one thing, for the Liberal Party of Canada-
You are attacking the federal NDP.

Mr. Speaker, as I have been saying all afternoon, this is a very tough, complex issue. In order to handle the deficit, the debt of this nation, we have to expand wealth. We have to create more wealth. I make no secret, I am a single tax person. We have to reform the tax system. That gets more productivity going in this country, which will generate more wealth. That will ultimately give us the resources we need to look after the deficits of these hospitals.

Mr. Speaker, it occurs to me to begin my remarks by wondering what has happened to the government members. This is supposed to be a debate on supply, but we will have an opportunity, I gather, to hear from some government supporters before the debate is over.
This motion is before the House to give all of us an opportunity to look at the growing concern there is in this country about health care and to examine the position of all parties in this House, including Her Majesty's Loyal Opposition, which purports to hold itself out as an alternative government in this country. It is important that the people of Canada get an opportunity to hear the position of the Liberal Party on this critical issue because all Canadians have been concerned increasingly about the state of our health care and, in particular, our medical insurance program in this country.
The concern began with the successive cutbacks in federal support for medicare, health and education programs. The concern rose further during the free trade debate when it became clear that the government was trading away vital protection for our social programs and beginning to join with the United States in driving down our medicare, our health programs and our social programs in order to harmonize, as the word was, our economy with that of the United States. Concerns were raised during the election campaign and never properly answered. We have seen since that election the government continuing on its path to deprive the provinces of the necessary financial support to sustain a universal,
public medical care program in this country. Now that program is under attack.
What we see in the Liberal provinces of this country are the cracks beginning in the principle of universality, accessibility of public medicare in this country. It thus becomes critically important that we hear from the Liberal Party in this House its position. What is intriguing is that in the debate so far, we have not heard the federal Liberal Party make a clear, unequivocal commitment against user fees and deterrent fees for health care. We are still waiting for the federal Liberal Party to make that commitment.
I rise in this debate because I want to recall for the Canadian people some history about medicare.
Ha.

My Liberal friend says "Ha". She says "Ha". Let us take it back a bit. The Liberal Party first promised health insurance in this country in 1919. In 1919 it was promised. Election after election after election the Liberal Party promised health insurance and election after election, despite the fact that in virtually all of the elections after that period they formed a majority government, they failed to deliver for the Canadian people.
It was only when the government of Saskatchewan in 1962, without any assistance from the federal Liberal government of the day-
Who was the government in 1962?
My friend makes a good point. It was the Conservatives that were the government in 1962.
Thank you.

I withdraw the allegation: without any support from Liberal governments despite 50 years of promises. When they were finally thrown out by the Canadian people in 1957, what happened? It was only then that the NDP government in Saskatchewan, all alone, without federal support, introduced medicare into Canada. It was at that point and only that point, with the federal Liberals in a minority position in this House, that a national medicare system came into being.
I was in Saskatchewan during the doctor's strike in 1962 against the NDP legislation introduced by the Woodrow Lloyd government, following the government of Tommy Douglas. It was the Liberals who were on the
March 26, 1992

front line of the Keep Our Doctors Committee who opposed and fought and withdrew the services of doctors against the democratic decision of the people of Saskatchewan to bring in a medicare program. It was the Liberals who turned up later as candidates who led the attack on medicare in Saskatchewan.
I can remember the Hon. Paul Martin, Senior, who was Minister of National Health and Welfare for many years, who took the kind of typical Liberal line of the day, going back to Mackenzie King saying: "We believe in health insurance, but we cannot do it this year". There were always excuses as to why the Liberal party could not produce medicare. It was only when they were politically forced to by the pioneering legislative act of the government of Saskatchewan that the Liberal Party finally caved in and adopted a national medicare program.
Here we are now with government revenues in trouble as a result, I may say, of Liberal tax policies in the 1960s and the 1970s, giving away billions of dollars to the corporate sector in this country, putting the government in irremedial debt, compounded by the high interest policies of this government which has driven us into a recession so that our health services are now again in trouble.
One thing needs to be clear. That is that our party is unequivocally committed to a universal medicare program. We have been in the past, we are today and we will be in the future. We are unalterably opposed to the use of user fees or deterrent fees as a way of bailing out the health care system from the economic ruin the Conservative and Liberal governments successively have put this country into.
It is clear from all of the studies that user fees will not do what is advertised for them. They will not reduce health costs. They will simply transfer the burden of health costs on to those who are least able to afford it. We cannot take a step in that path.
It is a real shame that we in this House have to debate the issues of the increasing pressure on this national institution of medicare. I think if Canadians were asked what it was that held Canada together, if they looked for a single symbol of Canada, it would be our medicare system. The underlying philosophy of the medicare
Supply
system is not that it is simply a service provided by government, but rather it is an obligation we as a community have to each of our citizens.
We have decided as a country that we want to ensure that medical services are available to all regardless of income and that income is no deterrent to access to medical services. That fundamental social reform that was enacted in a pioneering way in Saskatchewan and then spread across the country has become for Canadians a part of our national heritage and it must not be touched. We must work to preserve it, but we must ensure that in finding the funds necessary to establish an efficient, effective and accessible health care system that we do not look to the poor, but we look to those who have been given so many breaks under the tax system of successive Liberal and Conservative governments.
Here we are fighting to hold a system that is in place. I wish to finish my remarks by saying that I hope that we do not see medicare as the last great social reform in this country. Not only can we preserve our medicare system as a right for all Canadians, for all members of the human family, but we begin to look at other programs in which this principle might be applied.
We have as we look around us the clear reform this country must now move to after we settle our medicare program in place and as we preserve it. Recently in Victoria, I had an opportunity to talk to many parents and child care workers. It is clearly evident that our child care system is in chaos. The workers are underpaid and in many cases, under-qualified. The opportunities and places are inadequate. It is clear that we must take the principles that underlie our medicare system, our universal, accessible, high quality medicare system, and apply that to child care so that the people in this country, particularly the new generation of this country, can have equal opportunity and access to good and high quality services. We owe it to our children.
We have seen in the comments made by Liberal premiers in this country that the Liberal commitment such as it was to medicare is now ending. We have not heard Liberals in this House rise to refute the substance of the argument. They shout with fury at the fact the point is even on the floor of the House.

It is important that this issue be clarified. I think we have heard the answer today and I look forward to the support of the rest of the members of this Elouse on this important motion.

Mr. Speaker, we are more than delighted to take part in the debate. Whatever your decision is, we will certainly go along with you.
The question to the member is simply this. Reflecting on part of what he said at his opening, somehow they always drag in the old free trade debate going back to the 1988 election in the sense that it is going to endanger or threaten our health care system in this country. It does hit a raw nerve.

Mr. Speaker, after watching this in the last five minutes, it is no wonder the Canadian people are puzzled as to what we actually do in this House.
To try to sort through some of it, and going back to the member's comments, I do appreciate the fact that there was a little confusion on his length of time. I appreciate his giving up his time to allow us to be engaged in this.
Going back to the old free trade debate, and the one that is always held up, and the idea that engaging in any kind of a trade agreement with any country in the world threatens our health care system, I want to go through a couple of numbers that I would like the hon. member to respond to.
They are in relation to the percentages of Gross Domestic Product, in other words, the resources of Canada that actually go into maintaining a health care system in this country versus the United States.
I agree with the member. We have the best health care system in the world. The fact is that we dedicated fewer financial resources to maintaining the best health care system in the world than the Americans did. They have one of the worst health care systems in the world.
In specific numbers, we dedicate about 9 per cent of GDP to health care, and in the U.S., the figure is 12 per cent. It leaves out 30 per cent of the population.
This idea of that threatening our system is bizarre. Why would we abandon a system that is cheaper to deliver than the American system?
March 26, 1992

Mr. Speaker, the fact remains that the American system is a complete hodgepodge and many employers in the United States do not have to pay any health insurance costs whatever.
Because of the free trade agreement, our companies and our employees are obliged to compete often against companies in the United States which pay no such costs. It is very clear that the government knew this when it signed the free trade agreement and it has imposed this pressure on the Canadian economy.
That is one element of the pressure that is now on our health care system, and we are seeing it come to pass. Another product of the free trade agreement is that we are in a terrible recession. Job after job has been lost and government revenues, particularly in the central provinces, have virtually collapsed.
The free trade agreement is a contributor to the problem, but it is not the only contributor to the problem. There have been others, and certainly the more recent economic policies of the government, the high interest rates, the GST, have driven the whole country into a terrible position. We all know that. The country knows that and I do not think we need to look past it to understand why our medicare system is now in a crisis.

Mr. Speaker, when I was listening to the member for Victoria during comments and questions, he talked about Mr. Paul Martin Sr.
I would like to indicate that he was an illustrious member of this Chamber and is a Canadian who tells us he has a real love for the country. He gives a real example of a social conscience in his books which I recommend that the hon. member read.
I am glad that for the first time-I had made this point repeatedly in the past, which the NDP had not acknowledged-the NDP, through the member for Victoria, has acknowledged that it was the Liberal Party that conceived of the idea of medicare in 1919.
Like any human being, an idea has to have a beginning. From the idea, the federal Liberal Party gave birth to our Canadian health care system.
In 1984 we continued to nurture it. Last year on March 19, 1991 we introduced in this House a motion that

recommits us to medicare. I am very pleased that for the first time the NDP has acknowledged that the Liberal Party of Canada conceived medicare, gave birth to medicare, and continues to nurture medicare.

Mr. Speaker, the memory of the member for Winnipeg North on these matters is a little short. The fact remains that the Liberal Party had to be pitchforked into it and despite promises election after election, it failed to keep it.
However, I do appreciate the belief and conviction that my hon. friend brings to the subject of medicare. It is unfortunate he has found himself in the wrong party. speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the President of the Privy Council
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, those watching us on television this afternoon must really wonder what is going on in this House when New Democrats continually attack Liberals and Liberals attack New Democrats. It is time for some members on this side to get up, but I suspect that it was arranged with the Liberals, because they are so eager to be in power that they told the NDP, "Attack us. We will know what it was to be in power".
Mr. Speaker, I commend you for your wisdom in accepting an amendment to the resolution. Everyone should perhaps look at what happened yesterday and the day before, March 24 and 25, in Toronto, even though some partisan attacks were made at the first ministers'
conference. The worst thing I saw there was when a premier told the Prime Minister that to get a constitutional agreement he would have to offer some economic incentive. I find it absolutely horrible that one would put this country's future on the same level as public works announcements or things like that.
Mr. Speaker, I congratulate you on accepting the motion that would remove all partisanship from it. I am pleased to mention that on the 25th and 26th, the first ministers met in Toronto. They came back with the agenda they had decided on February 10 and they agreed to share among themselves the various issues that they had put forward then. They worked together on ten fields of activity.
Mr. Romanow and Ms. Coumoyea agreed to handle the famous issue of effectiveness and efficiency in social programs, especially the difficult and critical matter of health care. They will speed up their work and I think that we will have at least preliminary results in two months.
Bob Rae and Mr. McKenna will look after training programs. Gary Filmon agreed to direct the work on interprovincial trade. Foreign trade will come under Mr. Harcourt, agriculture under Mr. Romanow, and infrastructure will especially interest or at least come under Mr. Cameron of Nova Scotia.
Fisheries will be Premier Wells' responsibility. The federal government agreed to concentrate on the issues of fiscal and financial co-ordination, another difficult and crucial area.
Regarding health care, it was decided to speed up the proceedings. Two months from now, there will be a meeting of federal, provincial and territorial ministers to discuss health care services. As I said earlier, Mr. Romanow and Ms. Coumoyea will be in charge of this sector.
In fact, the provincial premiers and the Prime Minister of Canada agreed, and perhaps we should realize this in the House as well, that all social programs including health care depended on the economy's capacity for generating employment and wealth. Earlier, my colleague referred to these difficult times. The fact is, to quote a colleague sitting behind me, they always want to blame it on free trade. Unfortunately we are in a period of economic restructuring, and we have to live with the problems this creates. There are considerable challenges to be faced, but there is no point in looking for scapegoats.
March 26, 1992

At the First Ministers' Conference agreement was reached on a number of principles, in order to help increase the economy's capacity to generate employment and wealth. For instance, in the discussion on trade barriers, it was agreed that it was vital to speed up reduction of those barriers. The Minister for International Trade referred to this again this afternoon. The question is often brought up in the House, but it is not something the federal government can deal with alone. Trade barriers are also and mostly a matter of provincial legislation.
However, if we take down interprovincial barriers to trade, there may be times when we have instances of unfair competition between various provinces. In any case, this item will be given careful consideration.
There will be a joint review of the potential trade challenges facing Canada abroad during the next decade. We are now talking about free trade between Canada and the United States, between Canada, the U.S. and Mexico, and we are faced with new developments in Europe. How will these trade challenges determine our position during the next 10 years? What about our relations with the Asian bloc, South America, and so forth? It is important for Canada to determine ways in which it can become a major intervenor.
Another item on which the first ministers agreed was that Transport ministers would consider what could be done about our national highway network. Some felt this was a modest beginning, but it is a start.
We must also consider that by developing our social programs to include an increasing number of programs for training and retraining, we may be making some people too dependent on the system, so that once these people have gone through the whole process of manpower training, social programs, social welfare at the provincial level, unemployment insurance, and so forth, it will be very difficult for them to get out of this potentially vicious circle.
We will have to start looking at ways to prevent this dependency on social programs. We also would like to encourage the private sector to invest in training. My riding, Beauhamois-Salaberry, is located along the
Supply
American border, and I think it would be wonderful if we could do some of the things that are being done in other provinces to discourage cross-border shopping. That is one of the items on which the 11 first ministers were agreed and where they intend to take some kind of action.
We were talking about economic growth. In conclusion, I would like to repeat what was said by Matthew Barrett, President of the Bank of Montreal, in referring to the economy but especially to the unity of this country: "The message is clear: a divided Canada will be far less able to meet the competition than a united Canada, and the sum of its parts will not be equal to the value of the whole".
These are difficult times for the economy but we are also going through a difficult time in our histoiy as far as national unity is concerned. The repeated partisan attacks we saw this afternoon in the House are certainly not very edifying for Canadians who are listening. I think we should use our precious time to do what we were elected to do and concentrate on the real problems, not only the problems besetting our economy but the problems of the neediest in a rich and prosperous country that is the envy of the whole world.

Mr. Speaker, I listened with a great deal of interest and I found it interesting that when a government member finally decided to rise and discuss this matter, he avoided discussion of health care and federal transfer payments completely.

Mr. Speaker, I first thank my colleague for congratulating us on taking part in the debate. If he and his colleagues had been less obstinate, we would perhaps have had an opportunity to participate before.
I know what my colleague said. In the beginning, we thought about creating this program. A problem we have in our society is that when our economists think of a program of course they always think in terms of growth at a constant rate. That is very common. When the health program was thought up in the early 1960s, there were going to be more and more people paying into it and fewer and fewer at the top drawing on it. On one hand it is true, but on the other hand we must still live with certain realities. The population growth rate has diminished, but when I look at the figures for the province of Quebec, and we have them for all the provinces, in 1984-85 transfers to Quebec for health were $8,153 billion. It is ironic to say that they declined because in 1992-93 they are $11 billion.
In Ontario they were $6 billion and are now $9 billion. In Manitoba they went from $1.1 billion to $1.9 or nearly $2 billion. In British Columbia, the hon. member's province, they were $2,260 billion and are now $3,292 billion.
The problem with these transfers though-and I agree with my colleague there-is that the amount transferred is always a little less than the demand. But in real terms it goes up.

Mr. Speaker, in your absence just a few moments ago, I was on my feet in the question and answer portion of a member's debate. I mentioned the fact that if the Canadian people were watching today, they would be totally confused as to what we were talking about, and some say arguing about, in this debate. It looked like NDP versus Liberal most of the day. They were not attacking us; they were attacking each other.
What I want to do is to read the original motion. I know there have been some changes to it. The motion put forward by the hon. member opposite states:
That this House express its concern at the threat to Canada's health care system expressed by the stated intention of the Liberal premiers of the provinces of Quebec, New Brunswick and Newfoundland to forego universality and to embrace user and deterrent fees for health services.
Looking at this motion objectively we can understand why it created so much concern on the opposite side of the House. If I or any member of this House wanted to go on the attack, to attack any provincial premier, it is pretty easy to do.
I can stand up here today and rail, point fingers at and criticize the province of New Brunswick. Yesterday they had to deal with certain realities in my home province of New Brunswick. It is the reality that comes with assuming power.
That is something that members opposite do not understand. It is a responsibility that you take on when you form the government. It would be easy for me to stand up here tonight and point my finger at Premier McKenna back in New Brunswick. I will allow the opposition in New Brunswick to do that but I am not going to do it. It serves no useful purpose for me stand up in this House and condemn Premier McKenna for some of the decisions that he had to make.
Why would any premier want to cut services in his home province, whether it is Clyde Wells, Frank McKenna or someone else. Even Bob Rae is an example. Why would they want to do it? The only reason they do it is because that aspect of responsibility that members opposite do not understand because they have not been there. They do not have to balance the sheet at the end of the day. They do not have to be responsible to the taxpayers. All they have to do is tilt and rail and criticize. Nothing will be accomplished in this House if we continually do that. It is awful easy for us to fall into that particular trap.
Yesterday in the province of New Brunswick the premier had to deal with that reality of governing. There are two things that he has to take into consideration, that this government has to take into consideration when it comes to dollars, we have to manage the finances of this country and we have to manage the resources that the Canadian taxpayers give us.
March 26, 1992

We are finally realizing in this country, and the provinces are realizing it as well finally, that there is only one taxpayer. There is only one of us and it does not make a bit of difference whether we are talking provincial, federal or municipal taxes. It is the same person who pays those taxes. It is the same person at the end of the day and the family of that person who pay the price if those taxes are not spent wisely.
That is the mistake we have made in this country for the last 25 years. I think the former Minister of Finance expressed it best about six months ago when he said: "For the first 100 years of this country we lived off of our resources", a statement which no one here will argue with, no one. In the last 25 years, do you know what we did? Again referring to the minister, "we lived off our credit".
The amazing thing we are finally realizing as governments and regardless of what party we take part in or belong to is that we cannot live on credit. At the end of the day there is a huge price to pay for pulling out that credit card every time we want to deliver services. That is what we have done in this country regardless of political stripe.
If we made a mistake as a party after coming to this place and forming the government in 1984, it is probably realizing that too late. I am not quite sure that the public was ready to accept the types of things we have had to do as a government to bring everything into line, but finally it is because we set the example in this House from the day that I was elected.
All of us in this House are the first generation of politicians elected in 1988 that have not been able to go back to our constituencies with cheque-books in our back pockets to fix every difficulty in the riding. That is the easy trap that politicians have fallen into in this country in the last 25 years: If there is a problem in the riding, write a cheque; the government will come good for it.
Finally we realized that all of those good intentions had a price and it has created a huge mountain of debt over this government. It has created a huge mountain of debt over provincial governments. The interesting thing about this is that the NDP of Ontario is finally realizing what that mountain of debt does to the ability of the premier to fix things back home.

Bob Rae will bring down his budget in the next couple of weeks in Ontario.
Who?

Bob Rae and his finance minister. If you want to be technical, the finance minister of the province of Ontario. When they have to come to grips with reality it is going to make us feds look like little pikers, because they have some real difficulties that they cannot dodge. They cannot duck that bullet of reality that is coming right straight at them, in the face.
He is going to have to do the same types of things that the premier of my province had to do yesterday. He did not want to do that any more than I would want to do it or Bob Rae will have to do it, but again it is called reality. It cannot be dodged. We cannot duck it any longer.
The interesting thing is that government in a sense reflect society as a whole. There is a strange chemistry that works out, that sorts itself out at the end of the day. If we look at government debt in this country in relation to Gross Domestic Product, do you know where we are in terms of percentages? We are right about at the 80 per cent range. In other words, with all the goods and services bought and sold and everything produced in this country, at the end of the day, we are right up there on the debt side, to about 80 per cent, which is very high.
On the provincial, municipal and federal sides of the equation it totals about 80 per cent. The interesting thing is that in the private sector we are almost at the same number. The other interesting thing about this whole equation is that on the individual side of it, individual consumer debt, you and I as citizens of the country are just about at the same percentage level.
Governments over the years have forgotten where those tax dollars came from and have just continued to overspend in these last 25 years. Finally we have premiers, prime ministers, cabinets and governments from coast to coast that realize we have to take control of this thing. Regardless of whether it is an NDP government in B.C. or a Fiberal government in Newfoundland, from coast to coast the premiers have finally decided that we have to work together on this matter to bring it back down to reality. If that means that we have to cut services or increase taxes to get it back on the road to recovery, that is what we are going to do. That is what the premiers are saying. It has nothing to do with politics, but it has a whole lot to do with reality. That is what this government is doing.

March 26, 1992
Supply
Our increases to the provinces have continued and will continue, but we are entering that part of the equation that has been missing for many years.
