that Bill C-289, an act to provide that Remembrance Day be included as a holiday in Public Service collective agreements, be read the second time and referred to Legislative Committee H.
He said: Mr. Speaker, it is with a great deal of pleasure and an honour for me to have had this bill drawn. For those who are perhaps watching and do not know the process here, private members' bills are submitted and a draw takes place. From that draw some bills are picked which are votable motions. I have been extremely lucky in this particular instance that this bill has been drawn as a votable motion.
Perhaps it was lucky for the 700,000 Legionnaires across Canada as well.

My colleague says: "Perhaps it was lucky for the 700,000 Legionnaires across Canada as well".
I want to go through what the intent of this bill is. It is a very short bill. It is Bill C-289 and the effect of this bill is quite simple.

March 26, 1992
Private Members' Business
The effect of the bill is that every collective agreement entered into pursuant to the Public Service Staff Relations Act shall do a few things. First, Remembrance Day is to be a holiday. Second, no employee in a bargaining unit shall be required to work on Remembrance Day unless it is essential for the public safety or public interest that the work be done on that day. Third, an employee who is required to work on Remembrance Day shall receive extra remuneration or benefit in respect thereof.
A lot of people would ask is that not the case already? It certainly was what I thought had been the case up until about a year ago.
Let us go back and talk a little bit first about what is Remembrance Day and why we honour those who have served and have given the supreme sacrifice of their lives in the pursuit of peace through Canada's Armed Forces.
Remembrance Day is celebrated on November 11. Remembrance Day services take place at the eleventh hour of the eleventh day of the eleventh month. That was the exact time in 1918 when World War I ended. For a period of time, between 1923 and 1931 or 1932, it was called Armistice Day. It was commemorated at the same time as Thanksgiving.
That changed in 1931 when there was an act of Parliament called the Holidays Act that recognized November 11 as a holiday, as it did with two other holidays. Therein lies some of the concern and some of the confusion and most of the problem.
A holiday does not really have any legal weight when dealing with collective agreements entered into by the Government of Canada under the Public Service Staff Relations Act. That is part of the problem.
Remembrance Day was not recognized in 1931 through the Holidays Act just to give people a day off to go to the beach or to have a long weekend. That is not the intent of the Remembrance Day. The intent of Remembrance Day is clear. It is for Canadians to honour by way of a special day those individuals who gave their lives in the pursuit of peace through the Canadian Armed Forces.
I want to give a few little statistics here just so it is clear for everybody. During World War I, Canada had a lot of troops that served overseas. Of those troops that served overseas, there were approximately 60,000 who
lost their lives. In World War II, there were over one million Canadians, close to 1.1 million Canadians who served overseas. A substantial number of them gave the supreme sacrifice of their lives.
Although there were fewer individuals, men and women, who lost their lives in World War II, it was still a tragic event. Young men and women who had chosen to serve their country in a time of need, collectively to stop the Nazi movement through Europe in an effort to go and preserve peace and give freedom back to oppressed peoples, to stop a horrible war, they went and paid the supreme sacrifice.
There were many mothers and fathers and sisters and brothers who lost their most precious loved ones during those conflicts.
Finally in the last year the Korean war was recognized as a war and those who served as full veterans. In the Korean war, 312 Canadians paid the supreme sacrifice. They never returned.
Remembrance Day was a day to remember those who gave the supreme sacrifice, who gave their lives. It was also a time for Canadians to set aside everything and reflect on the horrors of war. It was a time for Canadians to sit down and remember clearly that the price of peace is eternal vigilance.
I do not have to remind anybody in this Chamber that just in the last few years we had to debate a war. Not in the 1950s or 1960s, but we had a debate on the 1990s war in the Persian Gulf.
As a member from Dartmouth I know where most of the men and women who serve in the Canadian Navy on the east coast are stationed. We have the naval air support wing and CFB Shearwater and the Sea King helicopters.
I was one of those individuals who went down on the shores of Halifax harbour and watched with a great deal of pride but a lot of fear, as we sent our men and women from the Canadian Armed Forces into a potential theatre of war. We were lucky this time because in that war they all came back. They all came back, by the grace of God and a lot of skill.
But Remembrance Day is a special day. It is a day when we should always remember those who have gone before us.
March 26, 1992

The problem that we have is one that occurred about two years ago during the collective bargaining process between Canada Post and one of its unions.
It was a tough negotiation process. Both sides were entrenched in their positions and it was not coming along very well. It became the subject of an article which was reported in the news that Canada Post had indicated that Remembrance Day was a negotiable holiday for the employees of Canada Post. That shocked almost everybody. It certainly shocked the employees. It shocked the
700,000	veterans around this country, Legion members, that Remembrance Day might be a bargaining chip that can be bargained away during the collective bargaining process, particularly in agreements under the Public Service Staff Relations Act.
The federal government, in negotiating contracts, did not have any legal obligation to ensure that Remembrance Day was a statutory paid holiday. Indeed, there was no weight in law that compelled any government or anybody negotiating on behalf of the government not to negotiate away Remembrance Day. I always thought it was a given.
My father, who is a veteran, served overseas and was wounded twice. He actually served with Dan MacDonald, the former minister of veterans affairs for P.E.I. He was with the hon. Dan MacDonald when Dan lost his arm and his leg in Italy. I called my father. My father said: "This is ridiculous. Of course Remembrance Day is a statutory holiday, particularly in the federal civil service".
But that is by convention, not by statute. It is a difficult issue for some of us to grapple with because I did not believe it. We checked with the department and they were not sure. So we checked with the Library of Parliament. Sure enough, it came back that Remembrance Day, although it is a holiday under the Holidays Act, is not necessarily a day that has to be given as a paid holiday in collective agreements negotiated under the Public Service Staff Relations Act, or indeed under any other act like the Canada Labour Code.
Clearly what this bill tries to do is not to change the status quo because luckily until now the status quo has been that it has always been negotiated as a holiday to be celebrated on November 11. But what this bill does is to ensure that it will always be a holiday in federal Public
Private Members' Business
Service contracts, and that that holiday will always take place on November 11.
Picture it: The further we get away from World War I and World War II and the Korean war, the further we get away from those particular awful periods in our history, the less likely it becomes that the public is going to honour Remembrance Day the way that it was originally meant to be done. We all know that.
When I went to school, when I was growing up in Cape Breton Island, I clearly remember that Remembrance Day was one of the biggest days of the year. It was not a day that was a holiday. It was a day that in the weeks leading up to it we did essays, there were always poster contests and essay contests. We had people from the Legion who came in and talked about the war.
Then Remembrance Day itself was a big day. It was the biggest day in my town of New Waterford, because on Remembrance Day there was the biggest parade and everybody came out. Everybody came out because that little town in World War II, had the highest rate of enlistment per capita of any town in the British Commonwealth, in the British Empire.
It was a big day because there were a lot of families in that town who lost loved ones. There were a lot of people like my father, for whom Remembrance Day was the best day and the worst day of the year.
It was the best day of the year because he felt proud he had served and that his community, even in all those years after the war would still come out and honour him and his colleagues.
But it was a sad day for him. It was a day when he had to stand with his buddies and after the services, after the march and after the parade, they would go back into the Legion and sit down and shed a few tears and tell a few stories, because they lost some of their best friends. They were in slick trenches next to their best friends in the world when they lost their lives. Those memories are never, ever forgotten by those who served.
This bill is timely. There is one little problem with this bill. I thought most members of this House would be prepared to put a piece of legislation in place, in the spirit of co-operation in this House. It is something that clearly does not cause the federal treasury any further encumbrances.

March 26, 1992
Private Members' Business
It is not a partisan issue. But it clearly sends a message from the Parliament of Canada to those men and women who have served in the Canadian Armed Forces, to the families of those who have given the supreme sacrifice in fighting world wars and in Korea.
The message is that we do remember and we are prepared to take unusual steps, such as this bill, a one-page bill. It simply says: 'You do not have to worry. As the world changes and as we get further and further and further from those world wars and the Korean war, because the federal government is going to make sure that at some future point we do not have to worry about Remembrance Day being negotiated away so that somebody has an extra day in the middle of the summer, so it is more attractive to trade that day for some other benefit".
That is not why Remembrance Day was part of the Holidays Act. It was not so that someone got a benefit. It was so that we would all remember the horrors of war and to give thanks that we live in a country that is peaceful. Most of all, it is that we remember those young men and women who gave their lives in the pursuit of peace on behalf of Canada. That is clearly what the bill does. It does not do any more nor does it do any less than that.
I just want to point out a couple of other things because some members are still saying to me: "Are you sure this is not covered? Are you sure that under the Holidays Act the negotiators for the government through the Public Service Commission does not have to give it?" No, they do not have to give it.
In clause M20.01, it says this is a negotiated item. This is what was negotiated. It says: "Subject to clause M20.02 the following days shall be designated paid holidays for employees". It goes through the list and (h) is Remembrance Day.
If this was in law already it would not have to be a negotiated clause in the collective master agreement with the Public Service Alliance of Canada. This is the master agreement. It is a negotiable holiday. I do not think anybody in this House thought it was a negotiable holiday.
Treasury Board has some concerns, so I am told, and I understand it. Treasury Board says: "Well, we do not know that we should support this bill. Not because it changes the status quo, but it may tie our hands in the future from negotiating things in the collective bargaining process". That is exactly what I am trying to do. There are some crazy trends going on out there.
Remember that it was the post office, a Crown corporation that said in negotiations a year and a half ago that this was a negotiable item. The post office was the first to put it on the table. Maybe at some future time, when this government or future governments are having difficulty with the Public Service unions in the country it will say: "No, we are not going to give you Remembrance Day. We are going to hold Remembrance Day over your head until you give us something back".
It goes completely against the intent of the original legislation. It goes completely against the declaration of Armistice Day back in the 1920s. It certainly goes against the spirit of Canadians who have chosen over the years to keep Remembrance Day sacred.
Treasury Board is afraid this might create a precedent. Somehow somebody else is going to come in with another day and say: "We are going to make sure this is a compulsory statutory holiday that is in law and is non-negotiable".
That is a ridiculous argument. Remembrance Day is a special holiday. There is none other like it in Canada. We have the July 1 holiday. That is a very special day for us in this country. We have Christmas and we have some other holidays as well.
This is the one day that is not meant as a celebratory day. It is meant as a reflective day. We have to remember that it is there in honour of those individuals who gave their lives for this country. It is why it is called Remembrance Day. That is why it is not veterans' day. It is Remembrance Day, clearly.
The Treasury Board's concerns are a little deeper than that as well. We are trying to address this because I know that sometimes bureaucrats get on these things and think if it comes from a Liberal and they are working for the Tory government that they automatically have to find reasons why they cannot pass these things.
I understand that. These things happen. It is a partisan place. This is not a partisan bill, and I want to make that clear. Every member in this Chamber has a legion, as least one, in the riding. Some members have as many as nine. Every legion in the country that has been apprised of this bill has fully supported the intent of the bill. The president of the Dominion Command has written to the
March 26, 1992

three leaders and has written to the minister involved, the Minister of Veterans Affairs, indicating that he wants the members of this place to support this bill, not because it gives the legion anything that it did not think it already had, but because it makes sure that it does not lose what it thought it already had.
Legion members, every year when they go down to the cenotaphs on November 11, in many towns, villages and cities across this country, find that fewer and fewer people come out. In some parts of this country, the shopping malls are still open on November 11. This bill does not seek to change that, but it says the federal government, the Government of Canada, will make that Remembrance Day will not fall by the wayside as a bargaining chip in future collective agreements that come under the Public Service Staff Relations Act.
The Treasury Board is concerned that if this goes into law, it will remove the ability of concerned parties to structure benefit levels. Remembrance Day is a holiday for virtually all public sector employees. This bill is not designed to alter benefit levels or change anything like that. It is an effort to by statute ensure that the status quo does not change. That is it. That is all it does.
The Treasury Board is also concerned that this bill, if passed, would mean that thousands of non-unionized public servants would not be affected by it because of taxable collective agreements. The Government of Canada currently treats those non-unionized management personnel the say way, when it gives its holidays out, as it does its unionized personnel. It is a bogus argument.
The government is concerned most of all that if this bill passes it is going to set a precedent and that all kinds of other special interest groups are going to come in here and try to tie the hands of the Treasury Board and say: "Here are the days that you cannot negotiate that are going to be in law and you are going to have to give them to your public servants".
I urge the members of this House to do the right thing. It is not because it is my bill. Anyone could have put this forward. We all have legions. We have recently debated war, and some members of this Chamber, one of whom is the member from New Brunswick, even had children
Private Members' Business
who served in the Persian Gulf war. It is pretty close to us right now.
There is something we can do here that will show that this Chamber does work, that it is not always highly partisan and that it does recognize the contribution of those who have served the country through our Canadian Armed Forces. I am asking members of all political stripes in this House to look at this bill and see if we can put a very positive statement out from this House that is currently the subject of much criticism by the public. The members of this House can work together and pass legislation which will be of benefit to all Canadians and make all Canadians proud of the service that has been rendered by the men and women who have served in the wars in which Canada has participated.

Mr. Speaker, it is a pleasure to take part in this debate. I want to begin by thanking the hon. member for Dartmouth on his reference to my son.
It is a good point to pick up on this debate. I am not sure how old I look to the folks back home. I am not that old. I think I am the only member in this House who had a son who served on the ground in the Persian gulf war. He is only 22. I can remember the night that I had to make a big decision as to whether I vote in favour of us entering that conflict. It was probably one of the most difficult votes that I have had to take as a member of Parliament. I sided with the government and I sided in our defence of freedom and democracy and for the things we always stood for as a country. I am very proud of having voted in that way. I am very proud of what my son did in that conflict.
Now he is a veteran of a foreign war which was brought to my attention by the Minister of Veteran's Affairs one day. It is strange when he put it in that context; my son is now a veteran of a foreign war. It has a certain ring to it. Reflecting on what the member for Dartmouth mentioned, there is no group of people in Canadian society that we have higher regard for than those men and women who served us so well overseas during World War 1, World War 11, and the Korean War. We have a special place in our hearts for all those men and women. It is important for us to recognize that this evening as we debate this bill.

March 26, 1992
Private Members' Business
Their role was a very special one. We recognize in a very special way those respective roles in those wars. There is no group of men and women in the world that received more from the respective governments than the men and women who are veterans in this country.
In this moment in our history when we are struggling to keep this country together and maintain the Canadian unity we all desire, there is no group of people working harder than us for individual Canadians in the Canadian Legion. In my own riding, I have had numerous legions. As the members said, all of us will have at least one legion. I suppose if I added them up, there would be dozens of legions in my riding. It is a very rural riding and very wide spread. Just about every little town and village has its own legion. They have just done some remarkable things back in my riding in this Canadian unity debate. They set up their own little committees and their own task forces to examine Canadian unity and what it means to them.
I have tabled in this House some of their papers, some of their reports, on Canadian unity which were considered by our committee and have been sent to the Minister responsible for Constitutional Affairs. They are very reflective. They could only come from a group of men and women that had the sense of determination and search for freedom as in World War 1 and World War 11. These people certainly carry their share of a load in this country. I am speaking again for every constituency in this country.
What the hon. member is suggesting in his bill does nothing to heighten that level of observance for Remembrance Day. That is the thing we have to remember. It does nothing, because we observe it as no other country in this world does. Remembrance Day is for all the right reasons, because we know the sacrifices they have made and given for their country. In many cases they have given their lives. What it would amount to is a legislative benefit, and that is where I have a problem. A legislative benefit simply means one thing. There is a cost attached to it. If you are talking about sacrifices and costs, we can have an emotional argument which we will all accept. There is no cost too great for those people who served us. No one disagrees with that.
It does not heighten our awareness of that very special day.
Within the federal bureaucracy, the Public Service, there is a dollar attached to that recognition. At a time when all Canadians have had enough with taxes and government expense, what do we do? That is the question that we have to ask ourselves.
The best thing to do, obviously, is to pass this thing if we had no other considerations to make; just stand up and pass it, because it is the thing that would make us feel better at the end of the day.
With government comes responsibility, and it almost goes back to where I left off before we had our recorded votes this evening. With government comes responsibility, and governments for the first time are recognizing that every time we stand up in this House and pass something, no matter how small or how big, if it is a money bill, there is a price attached to it that the Canadian taxpayers have to pay. I guess we all pay because there is only one taxpayer, as I reminded you earlier today. There is only one.
That is where we have to reflect on this thing. What are we doing if we pass it? We are just putting a little bit more of a burden on the Canadian taxpayers.
Having been in business for a number of years before I arrived here, and most of the time strictly in sales in which you have to go out and make it happen yourself, every time there is a holiday and the country shuts down in a sense, it has something to do with productivity. We lose a days work or there is a day that the Canadian taxpayer has to make up for. There are only so many working days in the year.
We can count the number of government employees we have in this country. Let me go through some of those numbers. They are astounding figures. There are more than 210,000 federal employees, 187,000 of whom are unionized. The annual payroll of these employees is $7 billion.
With other considerations taken in, it comes to a total figure of something like $8.3 billion. Out of that, and this is reflective of this government and what we do for our Armed Forces, $4.2 billion is paid annually to the Armed Forces and the Royal Canadian Mounted Police.
There we go. One does not have to be a genius in mathematics to calculate what the cost would be. That is the part I want to emphasize. We recognize the holiday. We recognize the contribution of our war veterans like

no other country in the world and I am very proud of that.
Before I sit down, recognizing what we have done for our veterans, I want to emphasize what the Minister of Veterans Affairs did today for the veterans of Canada in Halifax. He announced today that this government will soon introduce legislation for Canada's merchant navy veterans. That is one that will bring a smile to the face of the member opposite because he has worked very hard for that. Many of us have.
Recognizing the special role that our merchant marine played in Canada's World War II effort is very good news for all of us.
To conclude, I want to use that announcement today by Mr. Merrithew as an indication of how seriously we take the veterans of this country. As I began, there is no group of people that has dedicated more or done more for the country than that particular group of people.
I am very pleased with what we have done as a government and I look forward to a continuation of this debate.

Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to rise to participate in this debate. In doing, so I want to start out by complimenting the member for Dartmouth on his initiative. He said in his opening remarks that any member could have done this and that is true, but he did it. I think he deserves a lot of credit from all sides of the House for this initiative.
It is an important bill because in a lot of ways Canada is slowly forgetting why we gather on November 11. It is because at the 11th hour of the 11th day of the 11th month we pause to remember those who fought for Canada. A lot of people fought and died.
When I hear the hon. member across the floor say that there is a cost associated with this bill, a cost associated with ensuring that at the very least federal public employees have the day off so that should they choose to, they can join members of Parliament at the cenotaph to remember and to lay wreaths, I regret the hon. member made that kind of comparison. The cost in human lives in World War I, World War II, the Korean
Private Members' Business
war and, may I add, some of our peacekeeping initiatives as a nation cannot be measured in dollars and cents.
On the other hand, this Bill C-289 takes the monetary aspect of Remembrance Day off of the bargaining table. Neither side can use Remembrance Day as a bargaining chip to deal with wage increases or fringe benefits or working conditions or what have you. That is the underlying significance of this private member's initiative.
I would ask government members, assuming that what we just heard from their member who spoke is symptomatic of their feeling about this proposal, to reconsider.
On the other hand, I would have preferred the member, and again the onus is on me because I have not done it, to bring forward a bill that makes it a national holiday, that forces all of us to lay down our tools to remember.
I can say to you that on Remembrance Day at the cenotaph in Thunder Bay, and I am sure it is the same in Dartmouth, Winnipeg, Victoria and Iqaluit, that members of our Royal Canadian Legions will talk about why the school kids have to be in school today and why the mall is open. They are pleased that the federal public employees have the day off. They are pleased that provincial employees have the day off. They are pleased that the municipal employees have the day off. They are pleased that those members of that bargaining unit, in conjunction with their employer, have decided to make that day a holiday. In effect, they have traded off a day off to remember for some monetary or language aspect of their collective agreement. As we know, at the bargaining table you do not get something for nothing.
This is an important bill. It is important to all of us who recognize what those men and women did for us in the three major wars and the gulf and the peacekeeping initiatives which they are still involved in. We have a responsibility to them and the memory of them to set aside a day to remember them and to celebrate the democracy that we have because they gave their lives or they gave up an arm or leg or whatever. We all know them and I suspect we all have them in our own family. Members have heard me speak in this House before about my father who was a member of the Queen's Own Cameron Highlanders, captured at the landing of Dieppe, and spent 32 months in a Nazi prison camp.

There are all sorts of stories like that. Yes, we hear about them on Remembrance Day. Sometimes the stories are a little embellished, as good story tellers are wont to do, but there is also a tear in the eye. It is an important day and we should recognize it as something more than to be bargained for at the bargaining table.
Look at the young people, the children of the baby boom who come down with their teachers to the cenotaph, who had been instructed in the history of World War I, World War II, the Korean war and, I suspect now, slowly they will be instructed about the gulf. They look in awe at these, dare I say it, old men in their legion uniforms marching, still in step, as they make their way to the cenotaph to honour their comrades. The very least that we should do is ensure that it is not a matter for the bargaining table.

Mr. Speaker, it is my pleasure to rise this evening to support this bill. I wish to congratulate my college from Dartmouth on the tremendous presentation he made here tonight. I do not think we really need to add that much to what he has said to convince people in this House that this bill needs to be supported.
I am seconding the motion for this bill mainly because I believe the the six legions in my riding would like me to stand in my place here tonight and to support this bill. I am sure that all legions in my province of Prince Edward Island and all Islanders know or remember what our veterans have gone through and deserve.
I would like to also congratulate our present Minister of Veterans Affairs for his announcement today in Halifax where he announced that the merchant marine veterans would come under veterans affairs legislation. This is something that is very long overdue. These people served in dangerous waters around the world, especially during the Second World War. I congratulate the government and the minister for finally recognizing the contributions these people made.
The previous speaker said that people are forgetting. Indeed, that is correct. I know the veterans in my riding are very afraid that people will eventually forget entirely the great sacrifice which they and their friends made in the first war, the second war, the Korean war. There is a fear among veterans that one of these days in the not-too-distant future, people will forget entirely and their great sacrifice will be something which we may have read about in history books when we were kids.
We have to remember that while they are viewed as old men today, there are still a few First World War veterans living. There are still quite a number of Second World War veterans living. The thing you have to remember about these old men, these old soldiers, these veterans is that when they went to war, they were kids. They were 17, 18, 19, 20 years old and they were put in a life and death position where they had to not only defend themselves and their comrades, but they were there with the attitude and the belief that they were not there as a waste of time or they were not there in vain. They were there to defend a great principle, the principle of democracy and freedom in this world. I have an 18-year old son. If he would have been 18 at the time of the First World War or 18 years old at the time of the Second World War, he would have been signing up to go overseas to possibly give up his life. It is quite a thing to contemplate. Yet many of these people who signed up were under age.
I remember being in Vimy a year ago last November. There was a celebration there with the oldest Canadian veteran of the First World War who is now living in Maine. He had signed up when he was 15 years old. He somehow got into the First World War when he was 15 years old. To think that these people were so young. Most of these people who died were basically kids. They were not people in their 30s or 40s. These were what we call today teenagers and very, very young men who were just beginning their lives.
That one of these days that we as Canadians will forget the contribution that they made is something that we should not contemplate.
This bill is a beginning. I disagree with the government member from Carleton-Charlotte who tied this in as a cost to the taxpayer. If we are just talking about civil
March 26, 1992

servants, they already have the day off through negotiations. To take it out of the negotiating process is not adding a penny to the cost of Remembrance Day.
We are forgetting that no wars of any great magnitude have been fought in this country. It is our people who went to Europe and to Asia to fight these wars. It is the 75th anniversary of the Battle of Vimy Ridge which was the battle as far as Canada is concerned. It was a watershed battle where we discovered our nationhood in many historians' views. We became of age in the Battle of Vimy Ridge 75 years ago.
As I said, I had the pleasure of visiting that grand memorial we have there. All around the Belgian plains and all around the French fields of Flanders you will see many monuments and many graveyards from the First and Second World Wars. The Europeans have had a long and bloody history that I guess our forefathers thought we were going to avoid when we came to North America to start a new life, that we would be no longer embroiled in the battles and the bloody wars of Europe. Such was not our fate.
In the fields of Flanders I think there are still five Frenchmen a year who are killed because of munitions that are coming up through the ground. Farmers who are harrowing and ploughing run over this still live ammunition and get blown up. There is on average still five French citizens a year who die because of the First World War.
You will see monuments there from South Africa and from the enemy which at that time was Germany. They have some fantastic monuments there remembering their dead. The thing about the Europeans is the respect, the admiration and the time they take to come to our memorials. The great respect that they had for the Canadian soldier is still there. They and their ancestors have gone through bloody wars. They have seen their country ravaged. They are very thankful for the efforts that the Canadians made to maintain their freedom, not just our freedom. It was the freedom of the Europeans, the freedom of France, the freedom of England and the freedom of all Europe. They still remember with great reverence the sacrifice that our Canadian soldiers made.
In conclusion, I ask this House to take this bill very seriously and to give a lot of thought to remembering our Legionnaires and our veterans when we are voting on this bill. I think if we do that we will be supporting this bill and we will be taking the first step into guaranteeing

that this Remembrance Day will always be remembered by the Canadian people.

speakeroldname: Mr. William Scott (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Veterans Affairs):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Veterans Affairs
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, tonight I am very pleased to take part in the birth of this veterans bill, as we may call it. We have to recognize the veterans.
We can be very proud of the role that they have played after the wars also. Probably when they returned, they came into a new world, after seeing a lot of destruction and everything else on the battlefields. They came back with the many experiences they had during the wars over in Europe and in other wars that they had participated in.
They brought back a lot of insight. They were great builders and have been great builders of our country. We can honour the dead but we cannot bring them back. I think that probably this is something we should be doing, we should show through our legions and through our other organizations what the veterans have done. Probably to many people this would be a lost history if we do not do something about it. This is why I am supporting this bill.
I think our veterans over the years have made contributions in many, many ways that has made Canada the nation that it is today from sea to sea.
We cannot look at just any one part of our country. Our contribution in the world wars, my friends, has been great. There is no one individual, no one party, or anyone else who can say we did this and we did that. We did it collectively, my friends, and we can be proud of this. We are proud in the eyes of the world, proud of the contribution that Canadians have made.
We are proud in the eyes of the world of what our legions have done to promote many things in our society. Look at the contribution they make to the younger generations, what they have done for our senior citizens, what they have done for all segments of our community.
You can go into rural Ontario, you can go into metropolitan Toronto, or any other major city in our country that you may wish to speak of, and I have been in to a lot of them. I have been to the legions in western Canada, I have been to the legions in northwestern Ontario, I have been in to the legions in the maritimes. We are proud. I am proud, very proud to attend a legion rally or function, wherever it may be, for the spirit that is behind it. This spirit is not enhanced in any one area, it is

Private Members' Business
a broad spirit, it is the spirit of the Canadian soldier in his war effort.
This is what we have to talk about, my friends. We have to be proud of that. We have to tell that to this growing world which is changing so very fast, changing every day; We have got to instil in them too what our soldiers have done in the wars in foreign countries, their contributions, as I have said before, to this great Canadian nation of ours.
They have helped toward building Canada into a better place to be. They have helped in fostering some group or some child who probably has had some obstacle in life that has prohibited them from taking part in the great society we have, in sports and in many other things. You see the wheelchairs the legion has provided and the programs they promote for making wheelchairs available to our seniors and our disabled.
This is why I think that we all should be very proud of our Canadian Legions. We all should be very proud when we attend Armistice Day celebrations, which our legions take a big part in. We should be proud in the community functions that would not exist without the Royal Canadian Legion.
This is why I can sponsor this bill. This is why I can speak on this bill. I want to speak on this bill in the spirit that encompasses our great country of Canada. In encompassing that great vast area that we are proud of and we talk about, we have to think we are not the only producers of our lifestyle. We have to think of these other organizations that contribute so much to making Canada what we are all so proud of today, the envy of our great nation to the south, the Americans. They would love to have some of the things that we have had and we have at this time which they probably for some reason or other cannot afford to have.
These are things that a small nation can take pride in and shows the spirit of its people. This is something we have to boast about.
We cannot leave the Canadian Legion aside when we speak about of the great spirit of our country. They have been a big part of it and we wish them to be in the future.
I hopefully will be participating at some other stage in this bill. I want to congratulate the sponsor and I think, as others have said, that it is probably something that is long overdue.

Mr. Speaker, I want to thank the House for the opportunity to speak on Bill C-289. I want to congratulate my colleague from Dartmouth for presenting this bill before the House and my colleague from Egmont for seconding it, which is an act to provide that Remembrance Day be included as a holiday in Public Service collective agreements.
This bill is about the traditional values that this country is known for. This bill is a tribute, as the previous speaker said, to the spirit of the Canadian soldier, the spirit of integrity, the spirit of someone who was there to make sacrifices.
When my colleague from Egmont talked earlier about the fact that some of our soldiers went over to serve in World War II at the ages of 17 and 18, he was so right. My father was a member of the RCAF. He was 17 years old when he was sent over to England and I remember him telling me on more than one occasion of his flights in Halifaxes and Lancasters, in planes that rattled and shook and the fear that they had, the nervousness that they had when they were flying over Europe.
I think that today it is almost impossible for us to imagine what it was like. I have a son 15 years old. I cannot imagine two more years from now sending him off to fight in a war, flying in a plane like a Halifax or a Lancaster. There would be no way.
It is very important for all of us to make sure that the very special day, Remembrance Day, is enshrined in the basic culture of this country. What we do not want to do is create a situation where this day can be diminished in any way, shape or form.
As the speaker said previously there is really no extra cost to the taxpayer. We are already giving this day to public servants to celebrate and bear witness. There is no additional cost.
By passing this bill we will enshrine Remembrance Day in a way that it cannot be diminished in any way, shape or form.

As time goes on and there will be fewer and fewer people with us who have that very special feeling of remembrance for those experiences in World War I, World War II, or the Korean war.
We are going to need the instrument, the Public Service of Canada, to make sure that memory is carried on. In remembering that day, we are also remembering values that are so important to making sure that the character of this nation stays strong.
This bill is on behalf of all of those people who have served in those wars for Canada, fighting for democracy, freedom and peace. In my own riding I know the members of Todd Morden Branch 10, the Royal Canadian Legion and the Greek Veterans Branch 265 would hold me accountable if I did not stand and lend by support on this bill. I am very happy to have had this opportunity.

Mr. Speaker, for several minutes, I have heard touching tributes to our veterans and legionnaires. Of course I share my colleagues' opinions on the importance of remembering what they did.
What I have trouble understanding is that this really has little to do with the bill that was presented. It does not seek to designate a national holiday. That is already done. What it attempts to do is to change collective agreements. It would meddle and decide for the union what should be in the collective agreement, without the agreement of the parties and without considering the federal Public Sector Compensation Act passed by the House of Commons on October 1, 1991. This is an affront to the unions which had hard times last summer, as we all recall.
Furthermore, this bill is a threat to management rights, in that our managers could no longer provide
Private Members' Business
services to the public unless public safety was involved. We have gone from the noble principle of recognizing our veterans and legionnaires to interfering in a labour agreement, and I find that unfortunate.
You will no doubt remember, Mr. Speaker, all the difficulties in applying this principle during a strike and that the Supreme Court had to deal with this question in the air traffic controllers' case nearly 10 years ago.
The worst thing about this bill is that it is unnecessary. To our knowledge, all Public Service collective agreements already provide for Remembrance Day as a paid holiday and any public servant required to work on that day is entitled to overtime. However, no collective agreement restricts management rights as drastically as Bill C-289.
Mr. Speaker, you are signalling me that my time is almost up. In conclusion I will say that I am sorry but, as I said at the beginning, this bill has nothing to do with giving our veterans due recognition. If we need such a bill to recognize our veterans, I think that something is missing somewhere. In its programs the government recognizes Remembrance Day, compensates workers for it and ensures that it will always be present in the minds of all Canadians.
